urn:contentItem:7V89-01R0-YBDY-R3YR-00000-00State under fire on burnt fences2009-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisPg. 3State under fire on burnt fencesKAROLIN MacGREGOR

TASMANIA'S peak farming body says the State Government has not acted quickly enough to help a farming family burnt out in the Epping Forest fire in January.'

Epping Forest farmers Antony and Eve Gunn lost about 19km of fencing, along with pastures and crops on their property Forton in the fire on January 22.

The fire, which closed the Midlands Higway for several hours, has burned out about 13km of the Gunns' internal fences, 10km of fencing along the Midland Hwy and about 9km of fences along railway lines.

The cost of rebuilding the highway and railway boundary fences is expected to be at least $181,000.

Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association CEO Chris Oldfield said hundred of hectares of the Gunn family's property was unusable until boundary fences are replaced and the State Government has done little to help.

``The Government had handballed the problem to their insurance advisers,'' he said.

``The Department of Infrastructure Energy and Resources has told the Gunns the review of their claim may take some time. That is simply not good enough. The fire was not the Gunn's fault. Fix it.''

Mr Oldfield said the State Government was dragging its feet on the issue.

``Farmers in Victoria are already having their fences replaced and this fire happened a month before the fires in Victoria,'' he said.

``We want the Government to provide immediate assistance to get this fixed, and immediate doesn't mean in six or seven weeks.''

Minister for Infrastructure Graeme Sturges said he was committed to fully examining the situation to see what assistance and Sate Government could provide.

``What Mr Oldfield needs to understand is that the Department of Infrastructure Energy and Resources had now received several claims in relation to the fire, not just from Mr Gunn, and accordingly the department has forwarded these to its insurance auditor for assessment,'' he said.

A proper process must be adhered to, he said.

Mr Oldfield said a lack of basic roadside maintenance by DIER was partly to blame for the fire, which was fuelled by long grass on the Midlands Hwy verges.

``This matter is urgent and comes on top of all the problems Tasmanian farmers, including the Gunns, are facing because of the drought,'' he said.

``These people cannot use their own land and have had to agist their stock.''

urn:contentItem:7V3F-Y510-YBDY-R4GV-00000-00Prince slams callous bushfire arsonists2009-02-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15Prince slams callous bushfire arsonistsDavid Murray

ROYAL SYMPATHY

London

PRINCE William has slammed firebugs who lit Victoria's devastating bushfires as callous.

William and younger brother Prince Harry paid their respects to victims of the fires by signing a condolence book at the Australian High Commission in London.

A statement issued on behalf of the princes said: ``Prince William and Prince Harry were deeply shocked and saddened by the forest fire disasters that have struck Victoria recently.

``They just wanted to pay their respects to the Australian people today, and let those who have been tragically bereaved and others who have been left homeless know that their thoughts and prayers are with them.''

In a brief chat with officials, William told of his sadness at the death toll and alarm that fresh bushfires were threatening more lives and properties.

He said he had been shocked to hear arsonists lit some of the deadly blazes.

``To actually deliberately do it is just so callous. It's very sad,'' he said.

They pinned yellow ribbons to their suits, before sitting down in the High Commission's Exhibition Hall to sign simply ``William'' and ``Harry'' on the condolence book.

A crowd mostly of young women workers from Australia House gathered on balconies to see the princes.

``Both of them were just softly spoken and calm. They asked us whether we were all Australian and if we had family affected. It was very impressive,'' one woman said.

The Queen and Prince Charles have extended their sympathies, and Princess Anne flew to Melbourne for the national day of mourning and toured fire-hit areas.

Prince Philip, was the first to sign the condolence book last week, followed by Prime Minister Gordon Brown and Opposition Leader David Cameron.

About 150 added their names when the High Commission opened at the weekend.

High Commissioner John Dauth said the princes were ``alarmed . . . by the further dangers with fires in Victoria''.

``I told them also about the overwhelming number of letters and contributions we've had,'' he said.

``The Prince (William) said he assumed that that was from expatriate Australians.

``He was surprised and I think pleased when I told him we have had very many letters from Britons, many of whom have sent in contributions of 20 quid here and 50 quid there.''

urn:contentItem:5PWY-GRT1-JD34-V2N2-00000-00Rural Markets2017-11-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisRURALPg. 20Rural Markets

November 6. Yarding: 192. Change: up 84.

There were more cattle for the usual field of buyers and demand was mainly steady though restockers were keener and paid more for light weight vealers.

Most of the offering was in good to very good condition with a run of D1 Friesian steers and a few cows bringing down the quality. Processors paid equal prices for the well-bred and well finished cattle but at times discounted the off bred or less primed ones.

Agents penned 81 steers, 44 heifers, 44 cows and 23 bulls. Processors paid from 280c to 290c for C muscled vealers and mostly between 245c and 280c/kg for their yearlings.

Restockers purchased to 304c for yearlings and then paid 362c and 400c/kg for light weight vealers.

There were some grown steers this week and the good quality C3 and C4 grades made 260c to 278c/kg.

The C3 to C5 grown heifers were from a lower 226c to a firm 252c/kg.

Some inconsistent pricing was seen in the cow sale as was reflected by the wider range in prices in most grades.

The D1 cows made 160c to 217c, C2 to C6 heavy and extra heavy weight cows sold between 205c and 234c/kg. One very good B2 heavy weight bull sold for 260c/kg.

urn:contentItem:4R9G-BT70-TWT8-Y1H8-00000-00Vic: Firefighters contain bushfire in western Victoria2007-12-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVic: Firefighters contain bushfire in western VictoriaShelley MarkhamMELBOURNE Dec 8

  Firefighters have contained a bushfire which has destroyed more than 5,000 hectares of scrub in national park in Victoria's west.
   The fire, in the Little Desert National Park, was started by lightning on Thursday as a storm front moved across the state.


   Department of Sustainability and Environment (DSE) firefighters on the ground, with the assistance of four water bomber aircraft, contained the fire before midday (AEDT) today.
   The fire, which was about 15km north of Mount Arapiles, had destroyed 5,200 hectares of scrub, a DSE spokesman said.
   "Burning out efforts by crews fighting the fire ... in the Little Desert National Park at Jungkum Track, 15km north west of Mt Arapiles, have been successful and the fire has been contained," a DSE spokesman said.
   "The fire has burnt 5,200 hectares of the park.
   "Fresh crews will continue to black out and strengthen containment lines today."
   Two smaller bushfires burning in forest near Portland, in the state's south-west, had not been controlled.
   DSE said that a bushfire burning about 12km west of Hotspur, near the Dartmoor-Hamilton Road, had destroyed almost 500 hectares of forest.
   "A forest fire is currently burning in the Dartmoor-Weccurra area and is approximately 490 hectares in size," the spokesman said.
   "This fire is not currently posing a threat to any communities."
   A second smaller fire, also near Portland, was still burning out of control 17km west-north-west of Heywood.
   One-hundred-and-twenty firefighters were also trying to contain another blaze in the Wilsons Promontory National Park, south-east of Melbourne.
   The fire was burning in terrain inaccessible by vehicles in the Lilly Pilly Gully area, approximately two kilometres north of Tidal River, the spokesman said.
   "It is estimated that crews will be working for a number of days to complete the construction of a hand trail (containment line) around the fire perimeter," he said.
   That fire had destroyed about 23 hectares of forest.
   The Bureau of Meteorology said a cold front was expected to move across Victoria late tomorrow, bringing with it showers.

They've forced good men and women to put their lives on the line and they have seen a lot of people lose their homes."</p><p> Mr Carr said the boys would be made to visit hospital burns units and meet arson victims as part of a new punishment regime introduced by his Government.</p><p> The Shoalhaven district fires settled somewhat yesterday but unpredictable wind gusts and high temperatures again closed the Princes Highway between Sussex Inlet and Conjola as the McDonald State Forest fire threatened properties and livestock.</p><p> Favourable weather and backburning earlier in the day stopped a fire east of the highway in the Conjola State Forest from sweeping towards Bendalong and Manyana.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:57GD-RDY1-JD34-V0C7-00000-00PRECAUTIONS are being taken to ensure public safety2013-01-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisP3LOPg. 3PRECAUTIONS are being taken to ensure public safety

PRECAUTIONS are being taken to ensure public safety this weekend as a wave of hot weather continues.

With a top of 40 expected today, residents are being reminded a total fire ban is in place for all of NSW.

Increased fire danger has led to the closure of state forests across the Central West.

Forestry Corporation of NSW regional manager Gavin Jeffries said all forests in the region would be off-limits to the public until midnight tomorrow.

"The weather conditions continue to pose a very real threat of damaging fire," Mr Jeffries said yesterday. "To ensure public safety and the protection of both private and community assets the region's forests are being closed to the public again today, and for the weekend.

"No hunting, camping, fishing, fossicking, beekeeping, motorbike riding or any other recreational use, or general access, is permitted in forests which are all closed."

No-access areas include Ben Bullen, Blenheim, Canobolas, Dog Rocks, Essington, Falnash, Glenwood, Gurnang, Hampton, Jenolan, Kinross, Lidsdale, Lowes Mount, Mount David, Mount Macquarie, Mullion Range, Newnes, Neville, Pennsylvania, Roseberg, Sunny Corner, Turon, Vittoria, Vulcan and Wolgan, as well as Macquarie Woods.

Trespass carries a maximum fine of $2200.

It's the second time this week all state forests in the region have been in lock-down due to severe fire weather. On Tuesday, the mercury was three degrees shy of a predicted top of 37.

"The forecast conditions for this weekend tick all the boxes that cause us to worry," Mr Jeffries said. "We're looking at 38 degrees on Saturday [since updated to 40 degrees] and 36 degrees on Sunday. There's a bit of relief on Monday with a top of 30 degrees forecast, but looking past that to Tuesday and Wednesday with 34 degrees and 35 degrees on Thursday shows there's more worrying times ahead."

Mr Jeffries said people should realise just how quickly a fire can move.

"Based on this weekend's conditions, our modelling shows a grass fire can travel at eight kilometres an hour. A forest fire can spread at three kilometres an hour, spotting as far away as six kilometres with flames as high as 25 metres."

Residents are being advised that those most at risk of developing heat exhaustion are elderly people, people with chronic diseases and people working or exercising in a hot environment.

NSW Health officials said people should drink plenty of water; keep cool; take care of others; and have a plan.

(know who to contact).

Police also offered a timely reminder to motorists about the danger of leaving children, the elderly or pets unattended in cars.

Assistant Commissioner Alan Clarke urged everyone in the community to plan ahead and be prepared for the hot weather.

"While everyone should be aware of the impending hot weather, there is one golden rule which should never be broken: never ever leave babies, children, the elderly or animals alone in a car even if the air-conditioner is on," Mr Clarke said. "You might think it is inconvenient to take your child or pet with you, even if it is to go and pay for petrol or pop into a shop, but the alternative could be worse."

urn:contentItem:7V38-00D0-YBDY-R2RT-00000-00Firemen prepare to beat scorcher2009-02-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 22Firemen prepare to beat scorcherMegan McNaught additional reporting AAP

EXHAUSTED firefighters are bracing themselves for a potential horror day on Friday.

A top of 38C is predicted, combined with northerly winds and a southwesterly change.

Firefighters will spend the next couple of cooler days creating dozer lines and backburning in an attempt to contain the fires before the weather heats up.

Victorian weather bureau forecaster Richard Carlyon said the wind change would happen about 6pm on Friday and could bring showers and lightning.

Department of Sustainability and Environment spokesman Kevin Monk said firefighters were able to downgrade urgent situations yesterday at Upwey in the Dandenong Ranges and at Daylesford, northwest of Melbourne.

At Upwey, a fire that started in the Birdlands Reserve on Monday had been contained but the CFA has warned nearby residents to be on the lookout for flying embers.

Mr Monk said 400 firefighters were at Daylesford, 110km northwest of Melbourne, attempting to contain a forest fire spread over 2800ha.

``The conditions are so dry that it only takes a small spark and the fire can race off,'' Mr Monk said.

Firefighters in Canberra yesterday stopped to mourn fallen colleague David Balfour, the only firefighter to die in Victoria's bushfires.

A guard of honour, comprising firemen and members of other ACT emergency services, saluted Mr Balfour's flag-draped coffin as it was carried into the Holy Family Church in suburban Gowrie.

Daughter Frances, 13, carried his yellow fireman's helmet, flanked by his widow Celia and children Alison, 13, and Daniel, 10, as fellow firemen took his coffin from the church to a waiting hearse.

Monsignor John Woods declared the firefighter a hero who died while repaying a debt of gratitude to those who came to fight Canberra's bushfire disaster of 2003. Mr Balfour, 46, died last week after being struck by a falling tree.

Meanwhile, Federal Environment Minister Peter Garrett will return to his musical roots to play a benefit concert in Melbourne next month for victims of the bushfires.

Mr Garrett will reform with his band Midnight Oil for the concert at the MCG on March 14. Another concert, which will also benefit victims of the Queensland floods, will occur simultaneously at the SCG.

The Sydney concert will feature international act Coldplay, while the Kings Of Leon are on the Melbourne bill as is Jack Johnson.

urn:contentItem:7V1B-2KY0-YB64-40MD-00000-00Policy 'needs more science'2009-02-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Policy 'needs more science'AFTER THE FIRESADAM MORTON, ENVIRONMENT REPORTER

VICTORIAN Government agencies lack enough specialised scientists to manage an expanding fuel-reduction policy, a leading fire ecologist says.

Kevin Tolhurst, a senior lecturer at the University of Melbourne's department of forest and ecosystem science, said a recent Government strategy released in December went "a long way" towards addressing problems in Victoria's response to bushfire, but did not reverse the current emphasis on bureaucracy over science.

He said land management agencies across the country often employed people "who are better at wordsmithing than knowing the actual area they are working in".

"Often we are more interested in having a policy document the Government can defend its position with than with having good scientific data," Dr Tolhurst said.

"We really struggle to have people with adequate expertise to look at the fauna or the invertebrates or the plants."

The Government has been accused of failing to do enough to ensure adequate fuel reduction, with some forest fire experts accusing it of giving in to the green movement.

Environment Minister Gavin Jennings last week said he expected the bushfire royal commission would support the Government's Living with Fire strategy, including the intention to burn at a faster rate and improve community fire education, response and risk management.

He said whether current burning rates - 400,000 hectares over the past three years - were enough was a matter for the royal commission.

Dr Tolhurst said ecology and property protection must go hand-in-hand.

But he said it would be about 10 years before Victoria saw the benefits of an improved policy, and warned that the Government's new strategy remained vague.

The state's former chief fire officer, Athol Hodgson, has been more critical, predicting the Living with Fire strategy would fail.

Risk management expert Ken Granger, from the Institute for International Development, said governments had too often taken a "file and forget" approach to reports recommending changes in managing fire risk - including a report to the Council of Australian Governments on the deadly 2003 Canberra fire.

The Victorian Parliamentary Environment and Natural Resources Committee last year recommended fuel reduction be increased to 5per cent of the state's bush each year.

The most aggressive fuel reduction policy in the country is in Western Australia's south-west, where 12 per cent is burned annually.

urn:contentItem:57FP-65T1-JC0X-K02M-00000-00FED:NSW prepares for catastrophic fire day2013-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSFED:NSW prepares for catastrophic fire dayCANBERRA Jan 8

  More than 20 uncontained fires are burning across NSW as thousands of firefighters stand by for some of the worst fire conditions in the state's history.
   As Sydney and nearby coastal regions prepare for one of their hottest days on record, Prime Minister Julia Gillard said there was good reason to describe the weather conditions as catastrophic.


   Of the 100 fires burning in NSW, 21 are uncontained.
   NSW Rural Fire Service Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons says none is posing any immediate threat.
   "But clearly, under today's conditions, we are concerned with those and we will be monitoring them very carefully," he said on Tuesday.
   There is a total fire ban on the entire state with temperatures in the state's far west predicted to hit 45 degrees, while Sydney will swelter under 43 degrees - making it the third highest temperature on record.
   People living in Shoalhaven, the Illawarra and the southern ranges face the most risk.
   The ACT also has imposed a total fire ban as fire fighters mop up a forest fire burning in the territory's south.
   "We are shaping up for one of the worst fire danger days on record," Mr Fitzsimmons said.
   "You don't get conditions worse than this, we are at the catastrophic level and clearly in those areas leaving early is your safest option."
   Overnight more than a million people were called by telephone or by SMS to reinforce the leave-early message.
   Ms Gillard, who will get briefings on the situation in NSW during the day, said it was important people kept themselves safe and that they listened to local authorities and local warnings.
   "The word catastrophic is being used for good reason," she told the Seven Network.
   A bushfire in Victoria's southwest has almost doubled in size with firefighters working overnight to stop the blaze impacting rural communities.
   About 500 firefighters and 10 aircraft worked to battle the Kentbruck blaze which had burnt out 7050 hectares by Monday night, threatening the rural communities of Drik Drik and Dartmoor.
   Drik Drik is no longer under direct threat from the blaze with warnings downgraded to "watch and act".
   The Country Fire Authority is closely monitoring northern parts of the state where a severe fire danger rating has been issued in anticipation of searing temperatures.
   Total fire bans have been declared in the Mallee, Wimmera, Northern Country and North East districts.
   Two crews of firefighters from New Zealand will be heading across the ditch to help battle bushfires in Tasmania.
   More than 100 properties have been destroyed by fire in the state since late last week, but authorities are warning the danger isn't over and a total fire ban is in place for Tuesday.
   Tasmanian Fire Service senior station officer Phil Douglas said around 40 bushfires were burning across the state on Tuesday with concerns held for out-of-control bushfires at Lake Repulse and Forcett in the southwest.
   He said strong wind gusts between 30 and 70km/h were expected to sweep across the state's south between midday and 3pm (AEDT) causing concern for communities north of any active fires.
   No deaths have been reported but emergency services crews are conducting property-to-property searches for human remains.
   Ms Gillard, who inspected the fire damage in Tasmania on Monday, said NSW was facing weather conditions the island state experienced late last week.
   But she is hoping for the best on Tuesday.
   "I would like to end this day with nothing having happened."

urn:contentItem:5D75-SM41-F031-X1DT-00000-00US can't tackle Ebola epidemic alone: Obama2014-09-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisThe World Today1:02 PM AESTABCJane CowanUS can't tackle Ebola epidemic alone: Obama

ELIZABETH JACKSON: The US president Barack Obama has used a meeting of the UN General Assembly in New York to issue an urgent warning that efforts to stem the Ebola outbreak are falling significantly short of what's required.

President Obama says countries aren't doing enough to prevent the death toll in West Africa rising to hundreds of thousands and possibly as many as a million, and he's warned the US can't tackle the problem alone.

Our North America correspondent Jane Cowan reports.

JANE COWAN: Speaking to world leaders gathered in New York, the US president gave a stark assessment of international efforts to stem the deadly Ebola outbreak.

BARACK OBAMA: I want us to be clear, we are not moving fast enough. We are not doing enough.

Right now everybody has the best of intentions but people are not putting in the kinds of resources that are necessary to put a stop to this epidemic.

They need more beds, they need more supplies, they need more health workers and they need all of this as fast as possible.

Right now patients are being left to die in the streets because there's nowhere to put them and there's nobody to help them.

One health worker in Sierra Leone compared fighting this outbreak to fighting a forest fire with spray bottles.

JANE COWAN: Barack Obama has already dispatched 3,000 US troops to Liberia to set up facilities and form training teams to help treat Ebola victims.

Congress has also approved the use of money left over from the Afghan war to begin funding the president's $1 billion request to help fight the outbreak.

But president Obama warned other nations the US doesn't have the capacity to deal with the epidemic on its own.

BARACK OBAMA: Do not stand by thinking that somehow because of what we've done that it's taken care of. It's not.

JANE COWAN: Almost 3,000 people have died from Ebola in the five West African countries affected - about half of those infected.

The outbreak which began in a remote corner of Guinea appears to have stabilised in that country but has taken hold of much of neighbouring Sierra Leone, which has put three more districts under indefinite quarantine.

Liberia is now the country hardest hit by the outbreak. It says it has secured imports of basic food staples until December but the disruption caused to its mining sector could trigger a recession next year.

Airlines have suspended flights while expatriate workers have fled.

The UN meeting heard from the Liberian president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf.

ELLEN JOHNSON SIRLEAF: Today we face perhaps the greatest challenge for we cannot allow the projection of a worst case scenario that over 100,000 of our innocent citizens will die from an enemy disease they did not start and do not understand, that the resulting effect will reverse our gains in malaria control and child and maternal mortality.

JANE COWAN: The World Health Organization director, Margaret Chan.

MARGARET CHAN: We should expect things to get worse before getting better. The UN mission on Ebola emergency response is in full emergency mode.

I ask all of you to put yourselves in that same frame of mind. Every day, every minute counts. We need to talk of course but we also need to act with speed and efficiency.

JANE COWAN: The UN chief Ban Ki-moon echoed that sentiment.

BAN KI-MOON: Today it is time for the international community to step up and help Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone continue on the path of development and stability.

JANE COWAN: The Canadian government says poor global coordination has bogged down efforts to deliver its Ebola vaccine to Africa.

The experimental vaccine remains in a government laboratory, six weeks after Canada promised to make it available to fight the deadly outbreak.

A third American patient to be treated in the US for Ebola is now free of the virus, while a fourth patient is still being treated in Atlanta.

The World Bank announced it will give another $170 million to fight the epidemic, nearly doubling its total contributions.

In Washington this is Jane Cowan for The World Today.

urn:contentItem:7TYS-MN10-Y9Y8-S0V9-00000-00At a glance: Where the fires are burning2009-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisAt a glance: Where the fires are burning

Hundreds of firefighters are still battling out of control blazes in north-east Victoria and in the Kinglake area this morning.

The complex of fires around Kinglake, Kilmore and Murrindindi have burnt about 117,000 hectares.

They have burnt through Kinglake and Kinglake West and the fire fronts are headed towards the towns of Taggerty, Alexandra and the Mount Disappointment State Forest.

There are threat alerts for the Gleburn, Toolangi, Chum Creek, Healesville and Yarra Valley areas.

Stuart Ord, from the Department of Sustainability and Environment, says firefighters cannot get into some areas.

"There are access problems in that Marysville-Narbathong area, there are trees across roads and the fire fighting people are having trouble getting to some of these small townships," he said.

In the state's north-east, crews from New South Wales are helping local firefighters tackle a 20,000 hectare fire near Beechworth.

It is moving towards the Kiewa Valley and there are threat alerts for communities around Myrtleford, Dederang and Ovens.

Fire authorities say the blaze is spotting well ahead of the main fire front and it may impact properties in the Kiewa Valley.

A blaze near Beechworth has burnt through pine plantations in Victoria's alpine area and is moving into the Kiewa Valley.

Crews in Bendigo are still trying to control a 1,200 hectare blaze on the outskirts of the town.

The Department of Sustainability and Environment's Stuart Ord says every available fire crew is working

'Stunning speed, ferocity'

Authorities are stunned at the speed and ferocity of fires that have swept across parts of Gippsland in the last 18 hours.

The Churchill fire in the Latrobe Valley was reported after lunch yesterday and by midnight had burned through the Strzelecki ranges and thrown spotfires as far as Yarram and Woodside on the coast.

It has burned through 40,000 hectares and is burning towards Carrajung South, Won Wron and Woodside.

The South Gippsland Highway is cut in a number of places between Sale and Yarram.

The Bunyip State forest fire is being pushed north-east by the southerly wind change and is pushing smoke and embers into a number of towns around Jindivick and Neerim.

The Road to Walhalla is closed.

The Princes Highway has been closed at Warragul and west of Sale.

urn:contentItem:5D7N-2YF1-JD3N-531M-00000-00Break out the popcorn for movie feast2014-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 22Break out the popcorn for movie feast

Whether the kids seek action, adventure, quirky animation or a certain gang of pizza-loving turtles, there's something for them these school holidays Guardians of the Galaxy (M, 121 min) WHO?

Chris Pratt and voices of Bradley Cooper, Vin Diesel.

WHAT?

Sci-fi adventure-comedy. A group of reformed space criminals must work together to save the galaxy.

WELL?

This Marvel Entertainment treat stands up well to repeat viewing. The M-rating is slightly deceptive, as most scenes are well inside the all-ages zone.

Which AGE GROUP under 5yo: 1/2 5yo - 8yo: * * * 9yo - 12yo :* * * * 13yo+: * * * *

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (M, 112 min) WHO?

Megan Fox, Will Arnett, Whoopi Goldberg and the voices of Johnny Knoxville, Tony Shalhoub.

WHAT?

Action adventure. With the help of an intrepid news reporter, a group of mutated warriors face off against an evil kingpin who wants to take over New York.

WELL?

The Turtles are back, but not in the family-friendly guise that most '90s nostalgists would fondly remember. The combat scenes are too violent and threatening for children, while the sleazy asides of the Turtles when co-star Megan Fox slinks into frame are an unwelcome bonus.

Which AGE GROUP under 5yo: * 5yo - 8yo: * 9yo - 12yo :* 1/2 13yo+: * *

The Boxtrolls (PG, 99 min) WHO?

Voices of Isaac Hampstead Wright, Jared Harris, Ben Kingsley, Elle Fanning. WHAT?

Stop-motion animation. An orphan raised by sewer-dwelling trash collectors tries to save his friends from an evil exterminator.

WELL?

If your kids could handle the creepier material in films such as Coraline and ParaNorman they should be fine.

Which AGE GROUP under 5yo : * * 5yo - 8yo : * * * 9yo - 12yo :* * * 1/2 13yo+: * * *

Planes: Fire & Rescue (G, 80 min) WHO?

The voices of Dane Cook, Julie Harris, Julie Bowen, Brad Garrett. WHAT?

Animation sequel. When Dusty learns that his engine is damaged and he may never race again, he joins a forest fire and rescue unit to be trained as a firefighter.

WELL?

Doesn't happen very often, but this spritely and involving sequel marks a dramatic improvement upon what was only a so-so original. With so few low-impact "entry-level" titles in release for very young viewers this holiday period, this will be a reliable choice for most parents.

Which AGE GROUP under 5yo: * * * 1/2 5yo - 8yo: * * * 9yo - 12yo : * * * 13yo+: * *

The Maze Runner (M, 117 min) WHO?

Dylan O'Brien, Will Poulter, Aml Ameen, Kaya Scodelario WHAT?

Action adventure. Thomas is deposited in a community of boys and soon realises they're trapped in a maze that will require him to join forces with fellow "runners" to escape.

WELL?

The violence makes it unsuitable for young ones. For boys 10 and over, though, this gripping flick will be their must-see holiday movie.

Which AGE GROUP under 5yo: * 5yo - 8yo: * 1/2 9yo - 12yo : * * * 13yo+: * * * 1/2

The House of Magic (G, 85 min) WHO?

Voices of Cinda Adams, George Babbit, Murray Blue.

WHAT?

Animated adventure. Seeking shelter from a storm, a cheeky cat named Thunder sneaks into a mansion owned by retired magician.

WELL?

A cheery, quick-paced bundle of fun for the under-10 gang. Made in Belgium (but voiced in English), it doesn't follow the Hollywood lead of cramming every scene full of sight gags and over-chatty voice talent. It's a refreshing change.

Which AGE GROUP under 5yo: * * * 1/2 5yo - 8yo: * * * 9yo - 12yo : * * 1/2 13yo+: *

The Giver (M, 97 min) WHO?

Brenton Thwaites, Jeff Bridges, Meryl Streep, Odeya Rush.

WHAT?

Drama. In a seemingly perfect community without war, pain, suffering, differences or choice, a young boy is chosen to learn from an elderly man about the true pain and pleasure of the "real" world.

WELL?

The best aspects of this intriguing future-shock drama will go right over the heads of kids under 10. However, there is plenty of quality food for thought for the rest of the youth demographic, especially those impatiently waiting for the next Hunger Games.

urn:contentItem:51N1-XCW1-F0JP-W26N-00000-00`Israel to apologise for flotilla killings'2010-12-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 11`Israel to apologise for flotilla killings'Abraham Rabinovich

THE rift between Israel and Turkey may be on the way to resolution, according to a report yesterday on the US-sponsored Arabic-language television network al-Hura.

The report said an Israeli negotiator, meeting this week with a senior Turkish diplomat in Geneva, had agreed to Istanbul's demands that Israel apologise for the killing of nine Turkish activists last May when a flotilla of civilian vessels attempted to break the Israeli naval blockade of Gaza. Israel had also agreed, the report said, to Turkey's demand that it pay compensation to the families of the dead. Both sides have confirmed a meeting of their representatives in Geneva.

The Tel Aviv daily Ha'aretz quotes Turkish diplomatic sources as saying the discussions have been ``very positive''.

Jerusalem has not commented.

The Geneva meeting is an odd fallout from the forest fire that ravaged Israel in recent days.

Turkish Prime Minster Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who had summoned home his ambassador to Israel six months ago and has spoken scathingly of Israel since, dispatched two firefighting planes as part of an international effort to subdue the Israeli blaze.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu telephoned Mr Erdogan the same day to thank him and expressed the hope that this ``will be a gateway to improving relations between our two countries''.

But Mr Erdogan appeared to brush aside this attempt at reconciliation by declaring that sending the planes was a humanitarian act in accordance with Islamic morals and there would be no reconciliation unless Israel apologised for the killings and paid compensation. Nevertheless, Turkey sent Foreign Ministry Undersecretary Feridun Sinirlioglu, a former ambassador to Israel, to meet in Geneva with Israeli representative Yosef Ciechanover.

An Israeli official told CNN the diplomats were attempting to find ways to diminish the tension between the countries.

``We regretted the deterioration of the relationship and we, of course, would like to see an improvement.''

Alon Liel, a former Israeli ambassador to Turkey and former director-general of the Foreign Ministry, yesterday said the departure of Turkey from the moderate Muslim camp left Israel more isolated than ever in the region as it confronts a bloc of enmity stretching from Iran through Syria to Hezbollah in Lebanon and Hamas in Gaza.

Turkey has also been hurt by its rift with Israel. ``Many are beginning to see it as just another Muslim country,'' Mr Liel said, rather than a unique Muslim country with feet as firmly planted in the West as in the East, with something positive to say to both.

A hostile relationship with Israel, he said, undermined Turkey's longstanding desire to position itself as a mediator between Israel and the Arab world.

urn:contentItem:459J-DXX0-0197-T11M-00000-00<published>1996-05-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:48:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Meningitis claims thousands A MENINGITIS epidemic that has been raging over four months in the west African state of Niger has claimed more than 1000 lives, official figures showed. The National Service for Health Information said 1188 people had died out of 12,316 declared cases.</p><p>Fire engulfs New Mexican houses A SPREADING forest fire engulfed 25 houses and forced more than 2000 people to evacuate their villages in northern New Mexico yesterday.</p><p>Residents fled the Red River ski resort as the 2833-hectare fire ran along a steep mountain ridge to within 11km of the town. Two thousand people from nearby villages were evacuated. In Lama, 25 houses were burnt.</p><p>. . . while storms strike nearby THUNDERSTORMS spinning off tornados and flash-flooding hit American states from Missouri to West Virginia, leaving at least three dead, officials said. Forecasters warned that more violent weather was likely from Kansas to Kentucky, across Tennessee and into the Carolinas. Three people were reported drowned, in Kentucky, Ohio and West Virginia.</p><p>More rats than people RATS outnumber people in Bucharest by 10-to-one but they are still way behind cockroaches at 200-to-one and mosquitoes at 100-to-one, according to statistics in a Romanian environmental magazine.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:44JM-VRG0-0197-T29R-00000-00<published>2000-05-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:48:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 15</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Atom bomb birthplace goes up in flames</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE site of the historic Man hattan Project, the US effort to develop the world's first nuclear bomb, was partially destroyed by a huge week-old forest fire, it was revealed yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "The historic V Site complex from the Manhattan Project has been lost," said Los Alamos Nuclear Laboratory spokeswoman Kathy Delucas.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AFP</p></bodyText></section><p>She said "two old white large wooden structures where we machined high explosives for the first atomic bombs" had been burned by the out-of-control fire, which was intentionally set by the US National Forest Service on May 4 to clear brush. The two atomic bombs dropped on Japan in August 1945, nicknamed the Fat Man and Little Boy, were made there.</p><p> Only one of the V Site's three buildings was unaffected by the fire.</p><p> "The high-bay building where the Trinity high-explosive assembly was configured" remained intact, Delucas said. Trinity was the code-name for the plutonium device that became the first nuclear test explosion on July 16, 1945, in New Mexico.</p><p> About 1600ha of the nuclear laboratory's 112km2 property had been scorched. Five trailers, five storage sheds, two cargo containers and a pickup truck had been destroyed.</p><p> Firefighters continued to fight the flames yesterday but Delucas said no more "permanent structures, scientific facilities or facilities that handle radioactive or hazardous materials have been burned".</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Vic: Extreme conditions in Victorian alps</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>MELBOURNE, Jan 20</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Firefighters in Victoria's alpine region face extreme conditions today as temperatures soar into the low 40s fanned by strong winds.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Calmer conditions overnight enabled crews to conduct some control work around the fires, including a blaze which came within seven km of the small town of Mt Beauty.</p><p>But their work today will focus on saving private property and protecting firefighters, many of whom are entering their second week of battling the blazes.</p><p>And with a total fire ban declared around the state today, fire authorities called on residents to remain vigilant.</p><p>The fires have now engulfed more than 65,000 hectares after being sparked by lightning strikes across the state's east 14 days ago.</p><p>During the weekend fires at Mountain Creek, Bald Hill and Razorback merged, while a blaze in the Pinnabar area south of Corryong linked up with blazes burning across the border in the Kosciusko National Park.</p><p>Work is also continuing to protect alpine resorts at Hotham, Mount Buffalo, Dinner Plains and Falls Creek.</p><p>Last night Mt Beauty residents were told to enact their fire safety plans when the fire began moving slowly towards the town.</p><p>Thirteen New Zealand firefighters with specialist forest fire knowledge will help relieve fire crews today, while 70 to 80 defence personnel should be available tomorrow.</p><p>A south-westerly change is forecast to sweep across the state today but is not expected to reach the alpine region until tomorrow morning.</p><p>Country Fire Authority (CFA) spokesman Peter Philp said Melbourne had been blanketed by smoke from a fire north of Wandong in central Victoria, which was contained yesterday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source O12</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>School's in, then out as fire strikes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">COLAC school students had their induction into the CFA interrupted by a fire on Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The 13 Year 12 students from Colac High and Colac College were learning the theory behind the CFA when the station burst into action as 25 firefighters were called to attend a forest fire at Yeodene.</p><p>Region six brigade support officer Martin Dow said: "They saw the whole station come to life and that was a real hook for them.</p><p>"It cut short their tour but they were able to listen to the radio traffic and hear the waterbombing Helitak helicopter dispatched."</p><p>Mr Dow said it was an exciting start to the new learning initiative, set up by the CFA and Colac Senior Secondary Campus, which would guide the pupils to become fully fledged volunteer firefighters.</p><p>He predicted the program, which is a first for Colac, had 'huge potential' and could be a real boost for country communities.</p><p>"Because of the movement of young people away from rural areas it is a constant challenge to maintain numbers and the vitality that young people bring to an organisation is important," Mr Dow said.</p><p>Colac High teacher Karen Hart said the project was aimed at expanding students' personal development skills through the Victorian Certificate of Applied Learning.</p><p>"The program involves the students joining their local brigades and undertaking their minimum skills wildfire training," Mrs Hart, who is a volunteer firefighter, said.</p><p>"The end result is students will become fully accredited CFA volunteers and active members in a number of local fire brigades including Colac, Cororooke, Barongarook and Winchelsea.</p><p>"The excitement is growing among them and they can really see the benefit of being involved."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:53HW-R941-F12F-F300-00000-00QUEENSLAND FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICE CREWS RESPOND TO FIRE INCIDENTS IN KOORALBYN, GORE, FAIRYLAND, MAREEBA, RAVENSHOE, ALLIGATOR CREEK AND HERVEY RANGE2011-08-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisQUEENSLAND FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICE CREWS RESPOND TO FIRE INCIDENTS IN KOORALBYN, GORE, FAIRYLAND, MAREEBA, RAVENSHOE, ALLIGATOR CREEK AND HERVEY RANGE

BRISBANE, Qld., Aug. 11 -- Queensland Fire and Rescue Service issued the following news release:

KOORALBYN - CAMPBELL DRIVE

Twenty-eight rural and urban firefighters are working to contain a large fire at Kooralbyn which has been burning since Tuesday. The fire is currently burning in a south westerly direction. There are 12 rural and urban appliances on scene as well as two aircraft that are water bombing the fire. Approximately 400 hectares of bushland has been burnt so far. There is currently no threat to property. Residents are reminded to be vigilant and if they are concerned their property is under threat should call triple zero (000).

GORE (WEST OF WARWICK) - CUNNINGHAM HIGHWAY

One urban and six rural fire crews attended to a large grass fire that started burning along the Cunningham Highway, Gore at 12:50pm. Firefighters were able to bring the fire under control at 2.10pm. No property was threatened by the fire.

FAIRYLAND (NEAR CHINCHILLA) - BURRA BURRI ROAD

One rural and two urban fire crews responded to a large grassfire at a private property at Burraburri Rd, Fairyland at 11.30am. A vehicle at the property was burnt in the blaze. A structure on the property was successfully protected by firefighters and crews were able to contain the fire and extinguish it by 1pm. There were no injuries or property damage.

MAREEBA - HASTIE ROAD AND HOOLIHAN ROAD

Firefighters have been able to contain a large grassfire that has been burning near Hastie Road and Hoolihan Road at Mareeba for the past two days. Crews are periodically monitoring the situation to ensure that the area is safe.

RAVENSHOE - NEAR CEMETERY ROAD

Queensland Fire and Rescue Service is monitoring a large forest fire 2-3km out of Ravenshoe in the State Forest. The fire is in inaccessible forest and poses no threat to properties at this time.

ALLIGATOR CREEK (TOWNSVILLE) - NEAR DUGGAN AND ALLENDALE DRIVE

Queensland Fire and Rescue Service crews are currently conducting backburning after containing a large bushfire that started earlier today behind Duggan and Allendale Drive, Alligator Creek. There is no threat to property in the area. Motorists driving in roads located in the immediate area are reminded to travel to conditions due to smoke haze.

HERVEY RANGE (TOWNSVILLE) - NEAR SHARPS ROAD

Two rural fire crews are currently conducting burning along Sharps Road to contain a fire that is burning on top of Hervey Range. Earlier today the Rural Fire Service conducted door knocking the sparsely populated area to warn residents of the situation. Residents are reminded to be vigilant and if they are concerned should call triple zero (000). Motorists driving in roads located in the immediate area are reminded to travel to conditions due to smoke haze. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

urn:contentItem:7X76-6631-2R6N-61YV-00000-00Study suggests logging increases fire risk2009-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisAPg. 1Study suggests logging increases fire riskRosslyn BeebyScience and Environment Reporter

Large-scale logging could increase bushfire risk for Australia's moist mountain ash forests, creating bigger fuel loads and drier, more combustible conditions, new research says.

A world-first study led by Australian National University ecologist Professor David Lindenmayer has found gaps in the forest canopy allow the forest floor to dry out, increasing flammability by as much as 50 per cent in some cases.

The team looked at the impacts of industrial logging in moist forests across the world, including tropical rainforest, North America and Russia's wet conifer forests and mountain ash forests in southern Australia.

Professor Lindenmayer said the study had "huge implications" for future forest management and bushfire control in Australia.

"We can't ignore the risks, particulary in the face of climate change. These trends are occurring in moist forests right across the planet. There are no excuses, no reason to claim Australia's forests are somehow different. We've got to face up to reality and do some serious thinking," he said.

The study, published by the international journal Conservation Letters found logging altered forest fire regimes by changing the amount, type and moisture content of fuels.

The paper's four authors include University of Maine conservation biologist Malcolm Hunter and Canadian Forest Service senior research scientist Philip Burton.

Professor Lindenmayer said the team wanted to investigate whether logging made forests more or less fire-prone. "This is a question that gets debated after any big bushfire, and we usually hear all sorts of uninformed opinions from lobby groups. So we said, 'Right, let's do some serious science.' We looked at moist forests because fires usually occur at a relatively lower frequency than dry forests." The team found logging changed moist forest microclimates, drying out understorey vegetation and leaf litter. Roads built for logging access also increased the number of ignition points for fires, and the area of forest edge susceptible to drying. The study said research published almost 15 years ago, found clear- felling of moist forests in southern Australia led to "the development of dense stands of regrowth saplings that created more available fuel" than if the forests were not clear- felled. Professor Lindenmayer, who has spent more than 30 years doing research in the mountain ash forests near Marysville, said decades of logging had "created a legacy of ecosystem disturbance that will be felt for centuries".

urn:contentItem:59NK-G941-F0J6-J3PN-00000-00When it comes to global warming, no country is an island2013-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisNEWS REVIEWPg. 4When it comes to global warming, no country is an islandPeter Hannam

Because Australia's weather is so variable, linking disasters to climate change will be a hard sell, writes Peter Hannam.

When Peter Smith, NSW's former chief climate scientist, recently briefed leaders in the Seychelles about how the Indian Ocean island nation should prepare for climate change, he began by explaining the need for action.

"They told me to stop," Dr Smith says. "They just said, 'We know it's happening. What are we going to do about it?"'

Back in NSW, before he left his post in March, Smith spent more than a third of his time explaining that climate change was real and why people needed to consider it. Even after the state's worst bushfires in decades, it's not clear he would get a more receptive audience now.

Long-time residents in fire-hit NSW recall big, early-season bushfires in the past, and even Prime Minister Tony Abbott, a Rural Fire Service volunteer, has ruled a link between climate change and the fires "complete hogwash".

One reason the Seychelles don't need convincing is that their monsoon season is already shifting, increasing fire risks and bleaching corals.

Australia's famous climate variability, though, makes drawing a direct link with global warming "incredibly complicated", Smith says.

Wild fires are complex. Their probability depends on weather conditions, the dryness of fuel and unpredictable human behaviour - witness the military's explosives training during elevated fire-risk days that caused the largest of the state's fires.

But joining the dots of causality between climate change and periods of extreme fire danger, or floods, or other exceptional weather, is probably to miss the point, Smith says. "Climate change is a long-term trend, it is not a single event," he says.

The trend has looked bad for fires across south-eastern Australia for decades. As the Bureau of Meteorology told a Senate inquiry this year, "the Forest Fire Danger Index (FFDI), which essentially 'sums' daily fire weather danger across the year, has increased significantly across many Australian locations since the 1970s.

"The number of locations with significant increases is greatest in the south-east."

Bureau data show Australia has warmed about 0.7 degrees since the 1960s, with spring showing the largest rise. This shift is particularly clear in NSW, with some of the state warming up faster than anywhere else in the nation.

"If temperatures are going up, fire risk is going up," Smith says.

The other components of the index are wind, relative humidity and dryness of fuel. Climate scientists say it is difficult to determine how wind and relative humidity will change with warming conditions.

For fuel, though, warmer temperatures point to worsening fire dangers in dry periods, such as in the middle of the year when Sydney and surrounds had a third or less of the normal rain.

"In a highly variable climate where it is warmer and you have still got the potential for very dry years, it can often become more risky," Roger Jones, a researcher at Victoria University and former CSIRO scientist, says.

So far this year, the national temperature anomaly is about 1.3 degrees, or about 0.3 degrees above the previous record.

November and December would have to chill to below normal for this year not to be ranked as Australia's hottest in a century of records.

Smith has no patience for policymakers taking a wait-and-see approach to climate change.

"The idea to put everything off because we're uncertain, is stupid," he says.

A second day of high temperatures predicted for Victoria tomorrow has brought a total fire ban for the state's north west and warnings of forest fire danger in the Mallee district.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The weather bureau said record high temperatures in Melbourne city and country centres today will be followed by another day of heat.</p><p>In Melbourne the temperature ranged from 14.1 degrees at 6.00am to 35.1 degrees at 2.45 pm, the highest November maximum in Melbourne since November 25, 1991, when the mercury reached 36.8 degrees.</p><p> The heatwave brought temperatures well above the old Fahrenheit century to country areas where maximum temperatures were into the low 40s in the north and north west of the state, with 43 degrees at Mildura, Ouyen, Swan Hill and Walpeup.</p><p> The 43.3 degrees recorded at Mildura was the hottest November day since November 17, 1980, when the mercury reached 44.5 degrees.    <br/></p><p> The heat is expected to affect the whole state again tomorrow, but the bureau said there would be some relief when a south westerly change will extend from the west during the day and at night to bring milder conditions.</p><p> Temperatures in the mid 20s are expected on Thursday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-41Y0-0048-T4GM-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="203"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P8H-NVX0-TXN5-S0P8-00000-00Melbourne turns up the heat again but change on the way1997-11-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Melbourne turns up the heat again but change on the waySTEPHEN CAUCHI

Near-record temperatures are expected across Victoria today, with a total fire ban declared in the north-western and north-eastern districts of the state.

There are also warnings of forest fire danger in the Mallee.

The weather bureau has tipped a top of 39 degrees for Melbourne today, just below the November record of 40.9, set in 1894.

Yesterday, Melbourne baked under a maximum of 36.2 degrees at 5.10pm, the hottest November day since 25 November 1991.

A Melbourne Fire Brigade spokesman said small grass fires were reported across Melbourne's western and northern suburbs yesterday evening.

The weather bureau's senior forecaster, Mr Ward Rooney, last night predicted an overnight temperature close to the November record of 26.2 degrees, set in 1901. The second-hottest on record - 25 degrees - was reached last Sunday.

Mr Rooney said hot air blown from central Australia caused the high temperatures.

He said there would be a cool change early this afternoon as a south-westerly wind brought a small chance of rain or a thunderstorm.

He said that despite the hot spell, rainfall for November was about average.

Country areas to the north can expect a repeat of yesterday's low-40s temperatures - Mildura, Swan Hill and Ouyen hit 43 degrees.

urn:contentItem:56M4-HF71-F0JP-W2DW-00000-00A soundtrack for the cityscape Busker John Butler lets his music tell the inside story of a life2012-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisSAVVYPg. 204A soundtrack for the cityscape Busker John Butler lets his music tell the inside story of a lifeJane Armitstead

A YOUNG John Butler dreamed of joining the army, headed for a life of military discipline.

More than a decade later, he couldn't be more different.

Butler has had the world clinging to every note since he started busking on the streets of Fremantle when he was 21.

Flirting with the idea of becoming a pro skateboarder or art teacher, he couldn't fight his obsession with the guitar and his plans soon became one-eyed to live the life of a busker.

``Busking is such an unforgiving tradition people are there to listen to you because they want to,'' he said. ``They haven't bought a ticket and they have other plans than to see you.

``But if they stop and listen, it is a really big deal and I think it is a really cool thing that you can end up being a soundtrack for the day and you can make the cityscape that much more personal.''

Butler turned that personal experience into something the world has been captivated by for years and as he headlines theatres and intimate settings across the country. For his latest tour, he has gone back to where it all began.

``I guess it is going back to my roots and I get to tell a lot more stories and when I play by myself I end up talking a lot and bring my personal life to the floor,'' he said. ``It can get so intimate and intense that you can hear a pin drop.''

With a song he wrote more than 12 years ago, Butler recently released the first studio recording of Ocean in more than a decade as a free download.

Now, more than ever, the echo of the 12-minute instrumental will resonate through halls all over the country.

``That song is my call crier. If I was an animal it would be my call. It is my blueprint and keeps changing as I grow and it is always relevant and never gets old,'' he said.

``I played that song when I was busking and it always comes out slightly different. It is part of my DNA.''

For Butler, each note on his slide guitar (Dobro) is a memory of his late grandfather, after he inherited the heirloom when he was 16.

Butler's musical grandfather died in 1958 in a forest fire in the south west of Western Australia, leaving behind the guitar he used to play at family barbecues.

``All of a sudden I had this amazing guitar and I couldn't help but play and I quickly became quite obsessed by music,'' Butler said.

``The guitar is extremely close to my heart and I want to tell people the meaning behind it, but I want to tell them the full story at my show.''

After admitting he scares the children with his facial expressions while playing, he took time to control his own while Savvy caught up with him while he was taking some down time at his father's home in WA.

``Banjo is laying on top of me and opening my mobile phone. I don't normally let them play with my phone when I interview. So sorry, she is very distracting.''

>> John Butler will play at the Townsville Civic Theatre, supported by Mia Dyson, on Monday, October 1. Tickets are $50 from www.ticketshop.com.au or call 4727 9797.

urn:contentItem:4632-C060-015G-T38H-00000-00<published>2002-06-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:48:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 24</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Ranger charged over blaze</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DARRELL GILES</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">LOS ANGELES -- A female US Forest Service employee has been charged with starting the Colorado Rockies fire that damaged 40,000ha and threatened 45,000 homes.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Forestry technician Terry Barton, 38, admitted starting a campfire, but it got out of control.</p><p>Then she tried to cover up her involvement.</p><p> Ms Barton was patrolling the forest, warning campers about the dangers of accidentally setting off a huge forest fire. There was a fire ban in part of the forest.</p><p> She said she started burning a letter from her estranged husband within a designated campfire ring, where fires normally would be allowed, and then tried to put out</p><p>the blaze.</p><p> Bill Leone, of the US Attorney's Office, said Ms Barton told investigators she reported a fire -- but not that she had started it.</p><p> This led the Forest Service to question what she was saying.</p><p> "She attempted to suppress the fire but it grew," Mr Leone said.</p><p> Ms Barton was charged with setting fire to timber in the national forest, damaging federal property in excess of $US100,000 ($180,000) and making false statements.</p><p> If convicted, she faces up to 10 years in prison and $US250,000 in fines. She was scheduled to make an initial court appearance in a Denver federal court tomorrow.</p><p> "I want to begin by saying, this is one of the hardest announcements I've had to make in my career," said Rick Cables, regional forester for the Rocky Mountain Region for the US Forest Service.</p><p> Twenty-two homes were destroyed in the blaze.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:56MJ-5DG1-JD34-V4KS-00000-00RESIDENTS outraged at the approval of a granite quar2012-09-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisP3LOPg. 3RESIDENTS outraged at the approval of a granite quarBRIAN WOOD

RESIDENTS outraged at the approval of a granite quarry on the outskirts of the city without public consultation have called for council to lift its game in an effort to be regarded as being more open and transparent.

Bathurst Regional Council's decision under delegated authority to give the green light for the quarry on a property off the Ophir Road in Arrow Lane at Rock Forest drew a crowd of more than 80 people to a meeting on Thursday.

Councillors Jess Jennings, Bobby Bourke and Ian North attended the meeting at the Rock Forest Fire Station shed to hear the concerns of the residents, who believe road safety is the major issue that needs to be considered.

The newly-elected Cr Jennings told the Western Advocate yesterday that, in principle, he believes council needs to be seen to be more consultative.

"In this instance [over the quarry] this means explaining the delegated authority process and how it operates," Cr Jennings said.

"For the majority of the time it's probably just fine, but you can't expect everything to be perfect and to get it right every time.

"On the face of it, the residents' concerns sound valid to me. There are some environmental concerns, but the main issues are road logistics and the fact you will have trucks, school buses and other traffic on that road."

Cr Jennings said there isn't anyone who lives more than one kilometre out of town that couldn't relate to this type of issue.

"I live at The Lagoon, so I know," he said. "We [councillors Jennings, Bourke and North] will now relate the residents' concerns back to council and see what options there are in the short term," he said.

"However, the development has been approved and, at this stage, appealing to the goodwill of the developer seems the best option to me.

"I was amazed to see so many people at the meeting. There's certainly strong feeling in that community, with very real concerns about a traffic accident. There's several points where a bus can't even pull off the road."

Cr Jennings said that living at The Lagoon, he wants to be a voice for the villages.

"One point that was made at the meeting is that council is too city-centric," he said. "I want to make the point I live on a road similar to the one being discussed and can relate to the issues."

As to possible concerns that Bathurst Regional Council discussed too many issues in confidential committee, Cr Jennings said he's still too new to comment.

"However, I want to ensure this council is as open and transparent as possible," he said.

Bathurst Regional Council's chief town planner David Shaw said yesterday he passed the quarry under delegated authority.

"It's on the applicant's land and will be less than two hectares in size," he said. "The DA is to remove about 21,000 cubic metres of granite, which can be taken over 12 months or 10 years until the target amount is removed.

"It's a very small operation and is not within close proximity to any dwellings. There can be up to 10 truck movements on any given day, six days a week."

Mr Shaw said the developer has to pay upfront contributions for the upgrading of the Ophir Road and its intersection with Arrow Lane.

Pg. 7</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>New fire truck copes with 1000C</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A MILITARY-style fire truck that can withstand temperatures of 1000 degrees is expected to be in service in South Australia early next year.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Forestry SA yesterday took delivery at Kuitpo Forest, south of Adelaide, of the prototype of the FireKing, developed by Australian company ADI Ltd.</p><p>It expects to have the first vehicle in service by February and a total of 15 by late 2005.</p><p>The trucks will be leased under a $9.3 million agreement with ADI to replace the present Forestry SA fleet.</p><p>ADI managing director Lucio Di Bartolomeo claimed the FireKing was the only fire truck in the world with a tested crew-survival cabin.</p><p>Mr Di Bartolomeo said the cabin had resisted temperatures of up to 1000 degrees during testing by the CSIRO.</p><p>"During the testing, the internal cabin temperature rose by only 20 degrees," he said.</p><p>Forest fire air temperatures can range from 600 degrees to 1200 degrees.</p><p>During a bushfire, the temperature inside a conventional fire truck can rapidly equal the outside temperature.</p><p>Mr Di Bartolomeo said ADI had shown the FireKing truck to overseas firefighting authorities at its Bendigo, Victoria, engineering plant and was confident of other sales.</p><p>Forestry SA has plantations in the South-East, the Mt Lofty Ranges and the Mid North.</p><p>It also manages 24,000ha of native forest reserves.</p><p>Many of its firefighters are also CFS volunteers and the new trucks could be used to fight other bushfires.</p><p>Forests Minister Rory McEwen said the prototype vehicle would be used to train Forestry SA staff before the bushfire season.</p><p>"As a frontline bushfire truck, these vehicles incorporate safety and operational features specifically designed for the plantation forest environment," he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:49CY-5NM0-015H-P48W-00000-00<published>2003-08-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:48:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 3</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BRIEFLY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Crash death A MISSING Leabrook woman was found dead near her crashed car in scrub near Cudlee Creek last week. The woman was reported missing by her husband on Sunday, 17 August.</p><p>Tree to go</p><p> A SIGNIFICANT tree at Myrtle Bank will be axed after the Environment, Resources & Development Court overturned an Unley Council decision.</p><p> The 10m Monterey Cyprus Pine is on a Cross Rd block where three dwellings will be built.</p><p> Forest fire study</p><p> FIRE scientists presented the findings of a seven year study into the spread of forest fires to the CFS last week. The findings will be used to help plan back burn operations and combat bushfires.</p><p> Pokie decisions</p><p> DEVELOPMENT applications for gaming and pokie venues would be controlled by local governments, under a Burnside Council proposal.</p><p> The council voted to ask Planning Minister Jay Weatherill to give it control over pokie applications.</p><p> Darby St closure</p><p> FULLARTON Lutheran Homes on Frew St, are negotiating with Unley Council to buy and close adjacent Darby St. At a committee meeting last week, the council agreed "in principle" to the sale and would now begin the lengthy process required for closing a public road.</p><p> Kitchen for lease</p><p> KOUZINA Greek Kitchen's building on The Parade has been offered for lease by FPD Savills. But the restaurant's manager said last week he was unsure if it would close.</p><p> Houses approved</p><p> UNLEY Council's planning committee approved three row dwellings on a vacant block in Mills St, Clarence Park. Eight neighbours objected to the three bedroom, single garage dwellings.</p><p> Three new homes</p><p> THREE twostorey houses will replace a single storey building on Hallett Rd, Erindale. Burnside Council approved Bach Residential's application for the houses, despite one resident's concerns about overlooking.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:56GC-S111-DYG0-953Y-00000-00Highlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 Sept 22012-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSHighlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 Sept 2

  HIGHLIGHTS WORLD (ATTN EDITORS)
Highlights of the AAP world file since 20:00
    BEIRUT, Sept 1 AP - Syrian warplanes and ground forces have pounded the country's largest city, Aleppo and a new UN envoy has called for urgent change. (SYRIA)


   MTHATHA, South Africa, Sept 1 AFP - South Africa is holding funerals for most of the 34 miners killed by police in the worst crack down on a protest since apartheid. (SAFRICA LONMIN)
   KABUL, Sept 1 DPA - Afghanistan President Hamid Karzai has condemned what he called a "unilateral operation" by Australian troops in southern Uruzgan province, saying it breached an agreement with NATO. (AFGHAN AUST)
   CONAKRY, Sept 1 AFP - About 30 people are feared to have drowned after an overloaded canoe sank off the coast of Guinea, and rescuers saying they've given up hope of finding survivors after an all-night search. (GUINEA CANOE Wrap)
   LOS ANGELES, Sept 1 AP - Hal David, who with partner Burt Bacharach wrote dozens of top 40 hits for a variety of recording artists in the 1960s and beyond, has died. He was 91. (US DAVID)
   SEATTLE, Sept 1 AP - Richard Bach, the author of the 1970s best-selling novella Jonathan Livingston Seagull is in a serious condition in hospital after his small plane crashed in Washington state. (US BACH Update)
   LONDON, Sept 1 AFP - Queen Elizabeth II has attended the highland games at Braemar in Scotland alongside her husband, Prince Philip, who has made his second public appearance since being discharged from hospital last month. (ROYALS QUEEN)
   NEW ORLEANS, Sept 1 AP - As the remnants of Hurricane Isaac push their way up the Mississippi valley, spinning off severe thunderstorms and at least one tornado, some in Louisiana are impatient with the pace of restoring power. (ISAAC)
   NEW YORK, Sept 1 AFP - Apple has filed a fresh patent infringement action in the US against Samsung, alleging that the South Korean company is continuing to use its technology despite a recent court ruling. (LEGAL: APPLE SAMSUNG)
   LONDON, Sept 1 AP - Max Bygraves, a veteran singer and comedian known for his old-fashioned charm, has died in Australia. He was 89. (UK BYGRAVES)
   CHARLOTTE, North Carolina, Sept 1 AP - President Barack Obama has embarked on a four-day swing through battleground states and the storm-battered Gulf Coast in the lead-up to the Democratic national convention. (US VOTE OBAMA)
   CAIRO, Sept 1 DPA - A well-known television presenter has denied charges he attempted to incite the murder of Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi. (LEGAL: EGYPT OKASHA)
   BEIJING, Sept 1 AP - China's ruling Communist Party has promoted an ally of the country's likely next president to a key position ahead of a congress where a new generation of leaders will be named. (CHINA POLITICS)
   BAGHDAD, Sept 1 AFP - Iraq's oil exports reached their highest level in more than three decades last month as the country's output continued to increase, oil ministry officials say. (IRAQ OIL)
   TEHRAN, Sept 1 AP - Iran and North Korea have signed a scientific and technological co-operation agreement, bringing the two nations deeply at odds with the United States closer together. (IRAN KOREA)
   MADRID, Sept 1 AFP - Almost 4000 people who fled a deadly forest fire in mountains near the glitzy Spanish resort of Marbella have returned home after the blaze was brought under control. (SPAIN FIRE Wrap)

urn:contentItem:4SXB-8SJ0-TX4S-M0H6-00000-00TAX WORD with Mike Bannon2008-07-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisAPg. 41TAX WORD with Mike BannonThe Canberra Times

A NEW law that allows a tax deduction to businesses for capital expenditure on establishing trees in carbon sink forests has snuck into the Parliament. The law was introduced last year by the Coalition government and has been re-introduced by Labor.

Carbon sink forests are established to absorb carbon from the atmosphere, a process known as carbon sequestration. The carbon stored in the forest can be used for greenhouse gas abatement purposes. The costs of establishing trees are capital in nature and income may be generated from exploiting rights over the carbon sequestered in the trees. Establishment expenditure will be immediately tax deductible for trees established in the years ended June 30, 2008 to 2012. After 2012, establishment expenditure will be deductible over 14 years and 105 days at 7 per cent per annum.

Only taxpayers carrying on a business can deduct expenditure incurred in establishing a carbon sink forest. This will allow them to abate their emissions. The trees must satisfy the following conditions: At the end of the income year, the trees occupy a continuous land area in Australia of 0.2 hectares or more.

When the trees are established, they are expected to attain a crown cover of 20 per cent or more and reach a height of at least two metres.

On January 1, 1990, the area occupied by the trees was clear of other trees that could not satisfy the above dimensions.

Tax deductible costs will be: Costs of acquiring and planting the trees or seeds.

Costs of pots and potting mixtures.

Costs incurred in grafting trees and germinating seedlings.

Costs of allowing seeds to germinate (whether by broadcasting, deliberate regeneration or planting seeds directly).

Costs incurred on preparing to plant which may include ploughing, scarifying, contouring, top dressing, fertilising, weed spraying, stone removal, and top soil enhancement.

Costs of surveying the planted area.

Establishment expenditure does not include expenditure in draining swamps or clearing land.

Expenditure on other assets is not considered to be establishment expenditure. Examples include: Fencing.

Water facilities.

Roads within the forest.

Fire breaks.

The deduction will not be available for trees planted to be used in commercial horticulture. Mike Bannon is a tax consulting partner with Duesburys Nexia Canberra.
