urn:contentItem:4GJT-VYY0-015G-W0YV-00000-00<published>2005-07-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:48:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 13</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>DOOM & GLOOM</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">RIVIERA CAMPERS EVACUATED</p><p nitf:lede="true">ABOUT 5000 people  many of them foreign tourists  were evacuated from six camping grounds on the French Riviera today as an intense forest fire driven by high winds advanced on their tents and caravans.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire apparently started in three different areas around the village of Puget sur Argens, near the chic coastal town of Saint Raphael, and was raging through dry woodland.</p><p nitf:lede="true">BEAR KILLS ZOO KEEPER</p><p nitf:lede="true">A TAIWAN zoo keeper was mauled and killed by a bear today when he entered the enclosure to feed the animal.</p><p>Lee Chin-tsai, 41, was attacked by an Alaskan brown bear, which stands 3m tall, at the Leofoo Safari Park in Hsinchu, west Taiwan.</p><p>A spokesman said animal feeders were supposed to drive into the bear enclosure and leave the food when the bear was at a safe distance. Lee walked into the section.</p><p>LONE OCEAN SAILOR FEARED DEAD</p><p>AN 81-YEAR-OLD Japanese-American who sailed alone to Japan in a yacht to bury his wife's ashes in her homeland is feared to have died on his return journey across the Pacific.</p><p>Fishermen yesterday saw a drifting yacht, in which an apparently unconscious man was lying, 1400km off Japan's northern Pacific coast.</p><p>SIX GUNNED DOWN IN MOSQUE RAID</p><p>SIX gunmen were killed today in India after storming a religious site claimed by both Hindus and Muslims, prompting India to put security forces on alert nationwide to prevent sectarian violence.</p><p>Police and officials said the unidentified attackers shot their way into the complex in Ayodyha, site of the Babri mosque that was demolished by Hindu right-wingers in 1992 and triggered deadly riots across the country.</p><p>TWO POLICEMEN DIE IN EXPLOSION</p><p>AN EXPLOSION tore through a police post in the troubled southern Russian region of Dagestan yesterday, killing at least two officers and wounding three.</p><p>The blast took place in Makhachkala, the capital of Dagestan, which borders Chechnya, where separatist rebels have been fighting Russian forces since 1999.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier GLOOM</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CLIMBERS DIE IN MOUNTAIN PLUNGE</p><p nitf:lede="true">THREE mountain climbers fell 400m to their death in the French region of Montblanc today.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The two men and a woman, all French nationals from the Alpine Club in Le Mans, were descending when they lost their footing at 3700m.</p><p>And three people died on Saturday climbing Ukraine's highest summit in a group event whose participants included Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko.</p><p>About 16,000 people accompanied Yushchenko on the annual ascent up Hoverla Mountain, about 2000m above sea level in western Ukraine's Carpathian Mountains.</p><p>TOURIST PLANE CRASHES INTO SEA</p><p>SIX people, whom authorities believe were US tourists, were killed when their small plane crashed into the sea off Costa Rica's Pacific coast.</p><p>The accident happened on Saturday just off the coast of Flamingo beach, north-west of capital San Jose.</p><p>And a Russian-made plane believed to be carrying more than 50 passengers and crew has crashed deep in a forest in Equatorial Guinea, killing all aboard and leaving bodies scattered about the crash site.</p><p>FIREFIGHTERS PERISH IN FOREST</p><p>AT LEAST 11 firefighters have died in a forest fire raging out of control along a 17km front in central Spain.</p><p>A government spokesman said as many as 14 people may have died, trapped by the blaze that has scorched thousands of hectares in the Guadalajara area, east of Madrid.</p><p>SQUEEZE IS PUT ON INSURGENTS</p><p>US, AFGHAN and Pakistani forces have killed more than 60 suspected foreign militants and Taliban insurgents during the past three days in a series of clashes in restive tribal lands in Pakistan's North-West Frontier Province and neighbouring Afghan regions.</p><p>The fighting follows a warning by a senior US official last week that forces on both sides of the border needed to "squeeze" the region where al-Qaida leader Osama bin Laden might be hiding.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:56B4-WDP1-F0J6-J1YP-00000-00Close call2012-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Close callFirefighters halt Darkes Forest blazeANGELA THOMPSON

DARKES Forest residents breathed a sigh of relief yesterday as fire crews contained a formidable blaze above Bulli Tops which consumed 1600 hectares of bush and gave them a taste of what summer may have in store.

Wild winds fuelled the flames, forcing the closure of the F6 on Friday night and keeping residents in the area on tenterhooks.

Louise Murray said she saw the threatening bushfire when it was just a small blaze, flickering to life near Panorama House about 1pm on Friday.

As she waited for the fire brigade, she attempted to stamp out the embers, but the wind had other plans for them.

Within four hours, the fire had exploded into an inferno, consuming about 200 hectares of bush and scrub. It had also come alarmingly close to the homes of the Murrays and their neighbours on Darkes Forest Road.

Louise and her mother Leonie watched as the flames grew higher than their property's towering pine tree.

"The flames were probably 40 or 50 metres in the air," Leonie Murray said.

"It whooshed up the side of our property and we nearly lost our shed.

"We're one of the lucky ones, we've actually got a lot of clearings on our place, so we didn't feel too threatened.

"I could see it heading across to my neighbour's house," she said.

"It's gone now, thank goodness. Had it been summer it might have been a different story."

Mrs Murray's husband Peter and her son Ross, 20, are among 120 Rural Fire Service volunteers and NSW Fire and Rescue officers who had been battling the blaze since Friday.

It was finally contained about 2am yesterday but not before it consumed 1600 hectares of scrub and bushland and gave residents of Darkes Forest a huge scare.

The fire came within a few kilometres of the Darkes Forest Riding Ranch, prompting owner Robin Read to move her horses into an area with a secure water supply, and to launch other fire procedures.

"We take the rugs off the horses so they don't catch fire," she said.

"All the hoses are ready, the tanks are ready, the generator's ready - everything's in place.

"We've got to fight it with whoever's here.

"Over the last 30 years we've been through three of them [bushfires], so you put into practice the procedures you know.

"Everyone pulls together in this situation," Ms Read added.

Faced with boggy, inaccessible terrain, firefighters used backburning to limit the fire and dispatched several firefighting units to protect five or six isolated homes in the area.

The F6 was closed in both directions between Helensburgh and Bulli Tops on Friday night and reopened about 9.35am on Saturday.

There was no immediate threat to properties in the area yesterday, but the Rural Fire Service urged people to "continue to monitor the situation".

THREE PHOTOS: Black aftermath: Ross and Leonie Murray view trees charred by the Darkes Forest fire. Below: Flames leap high in the air during the fire's peak. Pictures: DAVE TEASE, ROSS MURRAY Feeling lucky: Residents Leonie and Ross Murray in part of the 1600 hectares of bush burned out by the blaze at Darkes Forest. More than 100 firefighters battled through Friday night to contain the fire, which threatened homes and forced the closure of the F6. Picture: DAVE TEASE

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Britain braces for a long, hot summer</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Frank Zeller</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Bushfires, drought, skin cancer warnings no, this is not Africa or</p><p nitf:lede="true">the tropics, it's the British Isles.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Britain is already suffering from what looks likely to be another</p><p nitf:lede="true">long, hot summer.</p><p>The traditionally rain-soaked island is bracing itself for water</p><p>restrictions this year, following a dry winter which has left</p><p>groundwater levels at record lows, the banks of the Thames exposed and</p><p>many farmers facing barley and wheat crop failure.</p><p>After several northern winter months of below-average rainfall,</p><p>January was the driest since 1779 and March only brought half the</p><p>expected rain.</p><p>This week a fire tore through the tinder-dry Dartmoor national park in</p><p>Devon and destroyed about 4sq km of heathland before 200 firefighters</p><p>could control the blaze.</p><p>It was the worst such fire in 20 years and was followed by a forest</p><p>fire in the woodlands of Cheshire.</p><p>A 61-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of starting the Dartmoor</p><p>blaze and later released on bail.</p><p>Meanwhile, Britons have enjoyed unseasonably sunny and warm weather</p><p>this week and cancer charities have warned sunbathers they risked skin</p><p>damage.</p><p>The drought has led one water company to announce plans for water</p><p>desalination plants to be built along the coast, similar to those used</p><p>in desert States.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4MX3-K420-TWT9-21W7-00000-00Vic: US crews sent into hot spots tomorrow2007-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVic: US crews sent into hot spots tomorrowMELBOURNE Jan 25

  Firefighters from the United States will be flown by helicopter into "hot spots" in Victoria's far north-east tomorrow.
   The 81 personnel, from 18 US states, today arrived in Corryong, near Victoria's border with NSW, after flying into Melbourne on Monday.


   Department of Sustainability and Environment (DSE) incident controller Rob Caddell said the crews were put through a further day of familiarisation exercises before they will tackle the Hermit Mountain blaze.
   "We have sent the US ground crews out to become familiar with the Australian bush conditions, and provide them with some familiarisation tasks such as driving and use of equipment," Mr Caddell said today.
   "Tomorrow the international crews will join others to be flown by helicopter into the fire's edge (where) their role will be to mop up hot spots along the western edge."
   The US contingent will remain in Australia for 30 days, returning the favour after Victorian crews jetted into the US during their past summer.
   "They came to the states this past summer when we were overwhelmed with a difficult fire year," US contingent spokesman Mike Ferris said today.
   "And we're thrilled to have the chance to repay them with our assistance and expertise."
   Fire crews from New Zealand and Canada are working on the Gippsland fires, burning in the state's east.
   Efforts are also continuing to remove koalas that survived the Framlingham Forest fire, in the state's west, where the blackened trees have been stripped of food.
   DSE wildlife officer Stan Williams said expert tree climbers hoped to remove about 150 koalas from the burnt-out 1,075 hectare bushland area that does not have wildlife corridors to other habitat areas.
   "Tree climbers are removing the koalas as the trees are very tall and there's no vehicular access for a cherry picker," Mr Williams said today.
   "The Framlingham Forest won't be able to support any for at least two years."
   Long-nosed potoroos, long-nosed bandicoots, eastern grey kangaroos and swamp wallabies affected by the fire are also receiving care.

There were widespread fires in Europe in the Middle Ages.</p><p> And in 1949, extensive fires spread from Spain, through southern France to Italy, destroying tens of thousands of buildings.</p><p> The worst forest fire swept over Wisconsin, Idaho and Montana in 1871, destroying 1.7 million hectares of forest and claiming more than 1500 lives -- the greatest loss of life in such a disaster.</p><p> Market opportunities appear and disappear and producers need to respond to these. Global climate change adds yet another dimension to the complexity of agricultural production'.</p><p>"Rural Australia needs to be at the forefront of the call on the Australian Government to act on greenhouse and to end the alliance with the 'big oil' dominated Bush Administration's opposition to international efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.</p><p>"The alternative will be more hot summers, more bushfires and droughts, more floods, more tropical diseases and pests and more stress on the profitability of Australia's rural sector," Senator Cherry concluded.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P6W-5090-TXN5-R28M-00000-00A flaky solution for global warming2005-04-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 3A flaky solution for global warmingDeborah Smith Science Editor

Dandruff and dog fur may be more than embarrassing inconveniences: they could be changing the world's climate, new research shows.

Dead skin, animal hair and other materials, such as bacteria, fungi, algae, viruses, plant cells and pollens, have been found to make up a larger part of "aerosol" air pollution than was thought.

By counting and identifying cells in air samples from around the world, a German researcher, Ruprecht Jaenicke, showed that about 25 per cent of atmospheric particles came from these sources in some places.

"Atmospheric aerosols play a crucial role in regulating the global climate, and the meteorological relevance of cellular particles could be high," said Dr Jaenicke, of the University of Mainz, whose results were published yesterday in the journal Science.

There is growing concern that airborne soot, ash and sulfur compounds from the burning of fossil fuels are reflecting back the heat of the sun and cooling the earth. This phenomenon, known as global dimming, could have led to an underestimation of the impact of global warming.

Suspended biological particles from plants and animals could have a range of effects on weather, said Dr Jaenicke. "Pollen grains attract water at a relative humidity well below 100 per cent and thus might act locally as cloud condensation nuclei, influencing the formation of clouds."

Decaying vegetation and marine plankton were excellent focuses for ice formation, so they could trigger rain, he said.

The samples, which included those collected during an eight-year period in Germany and a two-year period in Russia, showed the overall concentration of biological particles was steady throughout the year. But in spring there was more pollen and decaying cellular matter dominated in winter.

John Gras, of CSIRO Atmospheric Research, said biological aerosols had not received as much attention as other pollutants such as sulfur compounds and forest-fire smoke. He said more research was needed to test Dr Jaenicke's ideas.

urn:contentItem:4S4H-PF00-TX5J-V049-00000-00Fire fallout2008-03-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Fire falloutBy EMILY CHARRISON

THE State Environment Department was responsible for Belair's January bushfire which tore through 29ha of scrub and forced scores of residents to flee their homes.

A department investigation into the January 17 blaze, released last week, found it broke out when a tractor-mounted slasher struck a rock while creating a fire break on Brown Hill Creek Rd, causing sparks which ignited grassland.

The fire took about 120 firefighters and an army of CFS, MFS and department vehicles almost four hours to contain.

It burnt nearly 29ha of scrub and posed a direct threat to about 12 homes, while forcing hundreds more to either evacuate or defend their homes.

The department has introduced an interim work practice for its grass cutting until a state-wide policy is developed.

* Continued Page 4

Cutting practice overhaul

* From Page One

The department's operation planning and regional conservation deputy director Mike Williams said the new rules included:

m Until the end of the fire season Environment Department slashers must always be used by an operator with fire equipment kept nearby regardless of the fire danger rating;

m A 9 litre fire extinguisher and fire-fighting rack-hoe will be fitted to tractors used for slashing;

m Slashing will not be permitted when the Forest Fire Danger or Grassland Fire Danger rating is very high or above;

m Operators should undertake slashing early in the morning and only in areas of high asset protection.

Southern Lofty District Ranger James Crocker said Brown Hill Creek Recreation Park was recovering well in the wake of the fire.

``It only burnt about 3ha in the park so it had little impact on vegetation and wildlife,'' he said.

``We're already seeing some sprouts on Eucalypt plants and the olives tend to survive fire fairly well.''

Friends of Brownhill Creek president David Wagner said it was too early to determine the impact of the fire. ``It could revitalise some areas of native grass however it could revive woody weeds which have been dormant as they respond to fire,'' he said.

```But because we've had such a long, dry spell we haven't been able to see the impacts on the park.''

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Vic: Fire crews braced for Victoria's 13th day of fires</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>MELBOURNE, Jan 20</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Extreme conditions are forecast to hit Victoria today, as firefighters begin their 13th day battling bushfires that have threatened towns and Alpine resorts in the state's north-east.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A total fire ban has been declared across Victoria as more than 2,000 firefighters, backed by a team of New Zealand specialists, continue efforts to contain the huge fires.</p><p>Private property was under threat and, according to Department of Sustainability and Environment (DSE) spokesman Mike Leonard, work was continuing to protect alpine resorts at Hotham, Mount Buffalo, Dinner Plains and Falls Creek.</p><p>But Mr Leonard said he was confident property owners were ready for any onslaught.</p><p>"We've had 10 days to get ready for this," he said.</p><p>"Landowners have been making sure their houses are sealed up, fire breaks along their fences are in check, and their pumps work," he said.</p><p>A group of 13 New Zealand firefighters with specialist forest fire knowledge arrived yesterday to help relieve exhausted crews.</p><p>"They'll assist us with their skills, providing some expertise and fresh energy to help us up there," Mr Leonard said.</p><p>Discussions were also continuing with the army, with up to 80 defence personnel expected to begin work tomorrow, he said.</p><p>Fires around Mt Bogong, Mt Feathertop, Mountain Creek, Bald Hill and Razorback merged over the weekend to form one huge fire front.</p><p>Another fire, in the Pinnabar area south of Corryong, linked up with blazes burning across the border in the Kosciuszko National Park.</p><p>Mr Leonard said firefighters were braced for difficult conditions, with forecasters expecting strong westerly winds and temperatures in the high 30s today.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:44KK-YHF0-0197-F1GY-00000-00<published>2000-05-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:48:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 17</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Firefighters lose grip on $1b blaze</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">LOS ALAMOS: An army of 1000 firefighters on the ground and in the sky struggled yesterday to contain a New Mexico forest fire that has caused $1 billion in damages.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The wind-driven blaze has charred vast areas at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, the top US nuclear research facility.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Reuters</p></bodyText></section><p>The fire has forced thousands of people from their homes.</p><p>Despite the efforts of firefighters, the blaze spread across more than 14,600ha of scenic northern New Mexico, sending up huge plumes of smoke that were visible for hundreds of kilometres.</p><p>The blaze was deliberately lit last week as part of a forest management programme to avert just such disasters.</p><p>The winds increased again yesterday and left firefighters scrambling to hold on to the 5 percent of the fire they had contained on Friday night.</p><p> "This thing is growing and we don't know where it's going to end up," US Forest Service fire information officer Jim Paxon said.</p><p>The fire has destroyed 261 homes and and was now spreading in three directions all around the Los Alamos laboratory and was near a town and two Indian reservations. The laboratory has been closed because of the fire, but a few administrative functions could reopen as early as today.</p><p> Air monitors had detected no radioactive releases, but laboratory officials said they were still taking care to protect a warehouse containing low-level nuclear waste stored above ground.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5C3R-2921-JD34-V1CT-00000-00Globalisation: wealth for a mere few2014-05-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisPg. 25Globalisation: wealth for a mere fewJUDY HERBERT

GLOBALISATION is like the board game Monopoly - all the property and assets of the other players ends up in one corner and they are left bankrupt.

This is made quite clear as small businesses are closed down because they cannot compete with the avaricious greedy multinational corporations, the beneficiaries of globalisation.

Thomas Jefferson in 1802 said: "I believe that banking institutions are more dangerous to our liberties than standing armies.

"If the American people ever allow private banks to control the issue of their currency, first in inflation, then by deflation, the banks and corporations that will grow up around the banks will deprive people of all property until their children

wake up homeless on the continent their fathers conquered."

JOHN JOHN

Wesley Vale

The rich get richer

"The tiny elite of multibillionaires, the 85 richest people on the planet, who could fit into a double-decker bus, have piled up fortunes equivalent to the wealth of the world's poorest 3.5billion people."

So warned Oxfam in January as world economic leaders met in Davos, Switzerland.

It remains true, as Sean Ford claims, that great benefits have flowed from modern economies.

However, global leaders like Pope Francis are derelict in their duty if they fail to remind the world that there is something very rotten in the economic state of Denmark when up to one billion humans daily remain in hunger and extreme poverty,

while just 85 obscenely wealthy capitalists command half the world's wealth ($1.7trillion).

The Pope, who lived for years among the world's poorest, is not a Christine Lagarde, but he is acknowledged as a highly credible world leader.

Ethics and economic development must hold hands in sharing capitalism's gains.

TRISH HINDMARSH

Stowport

Taming the tongue

Much discussion is focused on discrimination.

In endeavouring to unravel such a complex topic, discrimination often discriminates against the original intention.

Attorney General George Brandis advocates the right to be a bigot, perhaps too strong a term.

Free speech gives tolerance and some will be offended, misunderstood and hurt as a result.

Sadly, this is the nature of a fallen society. So easy to speak in haste, never to retract the hurt.

To discern, consider another's circumstance, feelings and heritage, is in line with Christian teaching, and is at times poorly displayed.

Even the tongue gets a mention in the Bible, in James 3:5: "It only takes a spark remember, to set off a forest fire. A careless or wrongly placed word out of your mouth can do that," (The Message).

Name calling, rudeness and put- downs - Parliament question time needs to look in the mirror.

I am a Christian, committed to the teachings of Jesus.

When his name is spoken as a swear word, I am offended and hurt.

However, I don't sue or make a big deal over it.

FRANCIS WILLIAMS

Burnie

Contracts interstate

In addition to John Hudson's SMS (April 22) regarding government contracts being awarded to interstate companies, I was recently informed by a resident and contractor from Arthurs Lake that the irrigation scheme that will drain Arthurs Lake in

order to fulfil irrigation promises in the Midlands has been undertaken by a New Zealand company, with the pipes required supplied by a French company.

As if it is not enough that the premier trout fishing lake in Tasmania is to be ruined, this is just another insult to the Tasmanian people, who not surprisingly cannot find employment.

I can also assure Mr Hudson that the unions do protest against this sort of lunacy by our governments, but unfortunately do not have the power due to declining memberships to be in a position to force common sense.

By not joining unions, Tasmanian workers have brought this situation upon themselves.

Last one out, please turn off the lights.

JOHN NICHOLS

Devonport

Council charges

To Jim Campbell (The Advocate, April 25) - before you start throwing stones at other councils' building and plumbing fees, I suggest you look in your own backyard and see what the Central Coast Council's building and plumbing fees are.

RAY TUPPER

Burnie

urn:contentItem:4S4H-PDY0-TX5J-V1MY-00000-00Fire blamed on slasher Inquiry upturns new evidence2008-03-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Fire blamed on slasher Inquiry upturns new evidenceBy Emily Charrison

THE State Environment Department was responsible for Belair's January bushfire which tore through 29ha of scrub and forced scores of residents to flee their homes.

A department investigation into the January 17 blaze, released last week, found it broke out when a tractor-mounted slasher struck a rock while creating a fire break on Brownhill Creek Rd, causing sparks which ignited grassland.

The fire took about 120 firefighters and an army of CFS, MFS and department vehicles almost four hours to contain.

It burnt nearly 29ha of scrub and posed a direct threat to about 12 homes, while forcing hundreds more to either evacuate or defend their homes.

The department's operation planning and regional conservation deputy director, Mike Williams, said it had now introduced an interim work practice for its grass cutting until a state-wide policy is developed.

Mr Williams said the new rules included:

m Until the end of the fire season Environment Department slashers must always be used by an operator with fire equipment kept nearby regardless of the fire danger rating;

m A 9 litre fire extinguisher and fire-fighting rack-hoe will be fitted to each tractor used for slashing;

m Slashing will not be permitted when the Forest Fire Danger or Grassland Fire Danger rating is very high or above;

m Operators should undertake slashing early in the morning and only in areas of high asset protection.

Southern Lofty District Ranger James Crocker said Brownhill Creek Recreation Park was recovering well in the wake of the fire.

``It only burnt about 3ha in the park so it had little impact on vegetation and wildlife,'' he said.

``We're already seeing some sprouts on Eucalypt plants and the olives tend to survive fire fairly well.''

Friends of Brownhill Creek president David Wagner said it was too early to determine the entire impact of the fire.

``It could revitalise some areas of native grass however it could revive woody weeds which have been dormant as they respond to fire,'' he said.

```But because we've had such a long, dry spell we haven't been able to see the impacts on the park.''

urn:contentItem:7VHS-Y010-YBDY-R3K2-00000-00doom & gloom2009-04-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10doom & gloom

MUM'S FAECES BABY-KILLING BID

A mother injected her one-year-old son with his own excrement in a bizarre bid to kill him, a German court has been told.

Doctors were baffled by baby Carlos's acute fever and constant blood poisoning after his mum took him to a Berlin hospital.

Suspicious, they searched the handbag of his 39-year-old mother, Elisabeth Kuefer, and found syringes loaded with the youngster's own faeces, a Berlin court heard.

Judges adjourned the case for psychiatric reports on the mum, who is said to be suffering from Munchhausen Syndrome a psychiatric disorder in which people feign illness to attract sympathy.

ARRESTS MADE IN BODY PARTS CASE

UK police have made two arrests in connection with the discovery of a man's body parts strewn across the countryside.

The man's legs, arms and head have been found hidden near roads and in fields in the English counties of Hertfordshire and Leicestershire in recent weeks.

The suspects, aged in their 20s and 30s, were both arrested in London on Tuesday.

SOLDIERS KILLED BATTLING BLAZE

Fourteen soldiers have been killed while trying to put out a forest fire in a village in Nepal's mountainous northeast.

They were trying to stop the fire from reaching a hospital but some became trapped when the wind changed direction.

SHEIK INVOLVED IN TORTURE VIDEO

The United Arab Emirates has acknowledged a member of its ruling family is the man seen in videotapes torturing another man with a cattle prod and setting his genitals on fire, an American news network reports.

Texas businessman Bassem Nabulsi, a former business associate and adviser to Sheik Issa bin Zayed Al Nahyan, revealed still images from one of the videos.

Nabulsi is not the man being tortured in the video. The victim is believed to be a man who the sheik felt had overcharged him in a grain deal, Nabulsi's lawyers say.

CORNERED TIGER REBELS FIGHT ON

Sri Lanka's cornered Tiger rebels have put up stiff resistance despite calls for their surrender, the military says, as the UN ordered an urgent humanitarian mission to the region.

The army says the guerrillas are confined to a mere 10-12sq km of territory on the northeast coast, where thousands of civilians are trapped by the fighting.

As concern mounts for up to 20,000 civilians, UN secretary-general Ban Ki-moon sent a humanitarian team to a no-fire zone.

urn:contentItem:459P-KKJ0-0197-T1NS-00000-00<published>1998-05-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:48:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Firefighters die as Mexico burns</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Mexico City</p><p nitf:lede="true">ILL-EQUIPPED and overwhelmed Mexican firefighters are scrambling under</p><p nitf:lede="true">sweltering temperatures and bone-dry skies to snuff out the country's</p><p nitf:lede="true">deadliest of forest fires in 50 years.</p><p nitf:lede="true">On Tuesday, 19 volunteer firefighters died battling one forest fire</p><p nitf:lede="true">about 130km east of Mexico City.</p><p>Since January, 49 people have died,</p><p>most of them undertrained local firefighters who tried to hold back</p><p>flames with little or no protective gear, while 222,500ha have been</p><p>scorched by 9000 separate fires.</p><p>Clouds of smoke from more than 4000 fires have combined with Mexico</p><p>City's notorious smog to make health conditions worse than usual.</p><p>The fires were started by farmers clearing their land for planting _ a</p><p>slash-and-burn effort similar to the one in Brazil, where fires</p><p>ravaged the Amazon rainforest earlier in the year.</p><p>Normally, cooler weather and frequent rains help extinguish Mexico's</p><p>fires. But in this dry year, when weather patterns have been altered</p><p>by El Nino, the fires raged out of control.</p><p>The Mexican government is investigating reports that drug traffickers</p><p>set many blazes to divert army troops or to clear brush for planting</p><p>poppies and marijuana.</p><p>The Mexican government's response to the fires has been criticised as</p><p>incompetent.</p><p>Firefighters said they did not have enough water trucks or heavy</p><p>equipment to adequately fight the fires or enough masks and protective</p><p>gear to outfit everyone in their battalions.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:55S7-GRP1-JD34-V2T7-00000-00Tempers flare over SA burn-offs2012-05-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisEGNPg. 14Tempers flare over SA burn-offsLOUISE McBRIDE

EMOTIONS are running hot in the Upper North in the wake of another prescribed burn which got out of control and started a bushfire.

Following the The Wirrabara Forest fire earlier this month, lit by the Department of Environment and Natural Resources and Forestry SA, evidence has emerged that ground crews pleaded with their superiors not to go ahead with the operation because of unfavourable weather conditions.

Sources say they told Forestry SA that hot, windy conditions were too dangerous for a prescribed burn. Despite warnings from their own crew and local objections the fire was lit.

The 35 hectares to be burnt soon turned into 800ha as the fire got out of control and ripped through Wirrabara Forest.

This follows a prescribed burn lit by DENR on Paney Station part of the Gawler Ranges National Park which flared out of control in hot, windy conditions last year and burnt 16,000 ha.

Landholders are extremely angry about the threat to their lives and properties.

Country Fire Service crews, regional strike teams and water bombers worked along side departmental crews to try and control the fire.

But local volunteer crews were left to fight the blaze as government crews clocked off for the day.

Wilmington CFS captain Geoff Hitch said "there was no stopping that fire once it got away".

"It was just lucky that there were no lives lost or homes destroyed," he said.

Mr Hitch said while the department had the "right idea at heart", it had gone the wrong way about it.

"It was a silly decision to go ahead with the burn," he said.

"I think a lot of time and resources goes into these burns so there is pressure to get the job done when it is planned.

"They caused the problem and then volunteers were called in to fix it.

"Fair enough, we are there to help, but it is frustrating when it is their mess. They are paid, and then get to go home, leaving the volunteers to clean up after them.

"If there is a fire on a farm, the landholder will help local crews and stay and defend their livelihood."

The CFS issues permits for planned burning, and before the burn was lit there were concerns about the department meeting the criteria, including a lack of suitable containment breaks and a lax approach to supervising the fire.

The attitude of the department, however, has got locals fuming.

"It is their attitude to this situation. They just do not seem to care," Mr Hitch said.

"There are so many burns getting away and if it cannot be done safely, they need to be stopped doing it at all.

"Lives were lost in Western Australia when a planned burn got out of control and I do worry that people could lose their lives here."

Sources also report that one of the department's costly fire trucks broke down and was unable to be used during the fire, which may have contributed to more loss of land.

Member for Stuart Dan van Holst Pellekaan gave a speech in parliament on Tuesday, relaying concerns about the protocol behind prescribed burns.

"The reality is that this turned into an out-of-control bushfire started by a government department," he said.

"There is clearly something wrong with the system.

"This is not a once-off and we need to make sure it does not happen again."

DENR was contacted for comment, but had not replied before Stock Journal's publication deadline.

urn:contentItem:44DX-S9B0-015G-T06R-00000-00<published>2001-07-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:48:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 2</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Hand-in-abdomen surgery</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DARRELL GILES</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">DOCTORS in the US will perform revolutionary surgery on a forest firefighter by tucking his burned left hand inside his abdomen for three weeks in a bid to heal the skin.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Jason Emhoff survived the deadly Thirty Mile forest fire, north-east of Seattle, but suffered burns to over 25 per cent of his body.</p><p>Four young firefighters died and six others were seriously injured in the massive blaze at Winthrop in the Cascade Mountains on July 10.</p><p> In surgery yesterday, doctors grafted Mr Emhoff's own skin on to his right hand, but said it was unclear how functional the hand would be.</p><p> The unusual procedure will be done on his left hand because blood vessels were destroyed down to the tendons.</p><p> "We're going to make a little pocket in the abdomen and bury (the left hand) with skin on top of his fingers, so in three week's time the blood supply will grow into his hands," said Dr David Heimbach, director of the burns unit at Seattle's Harbourview Medical Centre.</p><p> Then doctors can graft skin on top of the new blood vessels, he said.</p><p> "Otherwise it won't take. It would be like trying to graft skin on to a tabletop," Dr Heimbach said.</p><p> The procedure, known as a Crane flap, has only been done once before at Harbourview.</p><p> Surgeons have already removed burned areas on both of Mr Emhoff's thighs, his right calf, right arm and forearm, and spots on his back.</p><p> He is expected to remain in hos pital for up to six weeks.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4RN5-4FC0-TX5J-V05S-00000-00TV EYE2008-01-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisTVGUIDEPg. 12TV EYE

The Guide takes a critical look at the best on our screens this week

The Closer

Channel 9, Monday, 9.30pm

* * *

THE story-line may not be the most original material, but this week's episode is made all the more compelling by some intense performances. The opening moments involve Brenda (Kyra Sedgwick, left) and her team's desperate search for Ruby, a missing eight-year-old. With all the evidence pointing to Roger Stimple, a creepy convicted criminal with serious mother issues, Brenda struggles to piece together the girl's whereabouts. Unable to contend with Stimple's disturbing dialogue, Sgt Gabrielle resorts to brutality, jeopardising his future with the force.

Big Sky Bears

ABC, Sunday, 7.30pm

* * * 1/2

RESISTANCE is futile when it comes to the charms of baby black bears Archie and Luke (above) in this documentary that follows them as they grow up in the mountains of Teton National Park in Montana. But beyond the gentle hum of cicadas and cheerful chirping of birds, Mama Bear has an exhausting and tough time protecting her rambunctious babies from daily threats, making for a nerve-racking viewing experience, particularly when Archie finds himself cornered by a hungry grizzly and later when a forest fire threatens them and their home.

Burn Notice

Channel 10, Tuesday, 9.30pm

* * *

THIS fast-paced and slick-looking new series continues to be a top choice with its snappy dialogue and easy-on-the-eye leading man Jeffrey Donovan (above, with Gabriel Anwar). Former Cagney and Lacey star Sharon Gless, who plays burnt spy Michael's hypochondriac mother Madeline, complicates things when she refuses to co-operate with her son, holding back vital information pertaining to his burn notice. Madeline is happy to speak, but only if Michael agrees to help her neighbour Laura, who has been swindled out of her life savings.

ER

Channel 9, Wednesday, 8.30pm

* * *

AFTER 11 seasons, Dr Kerry Weaver (Laura Innes, above) hangs up her scrubs for the last time when hospital bureaucracy spells the end of her tenure at County General. Luka aggravates everyone, including Abby, when he decides to sack Weaver. A shocked Weaver retaliates by butting heads with Luka and Dubenko and going against their wishes during crucial moments in two surgeries. Realising her worth, Luka decides to reject the board's cuts, but the situation forces Weaver to reflect on what's more important to her.

urn:contentItem:5DT7-YX31-DYTG-22BD-00000-00Drones: A bit of harmless fun or a national threat?2014-12-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:48:25ZLexisNexisAPg. B004Drones: A bit of harmless fun or a national threat?The Canberra Times

Drones: A bit of harmless fun or a national threat?

Soaring sales of drones have prompted safety concerns, writes Harry Wallop.

I t is a story out of a science fiction movie. On July 22, the pilot of an Airbus A320 coming into London's Heathrow suddenly spotted a drone at 700 feet; an unmanned vehicle of unknown mission and destination.

Neither radar nor air traffic control had picked it up. The operator of the drone was probably an amateur gadget fan, whose intentions were innocent, if idiotic. But what is to stop a terrorist trying something similar?

The UK Airprox Board, which is in charge of air safety, is due to report on the incident this week.

By next year, it could find itself much busier. This Christmas Day, thousands of people are likely to find a drone under the tree. For the technophile drowning in tablet computers, selfie sticks and wristbands that monitor your sleeping patterns, drones are this year's must-have gadget.

"So far, we've sold close to 10,000," says Oliver Meakin, managing director of Maplin Direct, an electronics website. His firm says sales have quadrupled this year.

Dixons, Amazon and other consumer electronic retailers report a similar surge in sales of drones.

These range in price from £30 ($57) to £30,000. The basic models are no more than little remote- controlled helicopters, with very short battery life and unable to fly higher than three or four metres.

But the pricey versions can fly for about 30 minutes, be controlled via your smartphone and travel up to 1.5 kilometres high.

Mr Meakin says his company usually only designates something as a drone if it has a camera attached, which is increasingly the case. This is one of the main reasons why drones have jumped in popularity: they allow the selfie generation to take spectacular pictures of themselves or their homes from the air. Not only is the quality of the on-board cameras pretty good in some drones, but the technology has progressed rapidly.

Ian Pearson, the founder of Futurizon, is a futurologist, predicting developments in the gadget world.

"These drones have fairly sophisticated gyro technology that allows them to keep mobile in the air," he says. "Previously, you needed quite a bit of skill to fly them. And the cost of that technology has fallen rapidly."

With sophisticated drones you can set them to follow your smartphone's GPS signal while you go skiing, for instance, or race down a track on a mountain bike; turning your family day out into a slick action movie.

Indeed, the biggest users of expensive drones are news broadcasters.

Why spend £1500 an hour hiring a helicopter film crew when you can use a far cheaper drone to film, say, a forest fire or flood? Surveyors and utility companies are also starting to use them to inspect power lines or leaking roofs; a safer and quicker alternative than climbing ladders or scaffolding.

But for all the exciting and fun possibilities, there are mounting concerns that thousands of consumers are getting their hands on a bit of powerful kit unaware of the risks and regulations.

As the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) makes clear, "unmanned aircraft, irrespective of their size, are still classified as aircraft; they are not toys".

You cannot fly them in built-up areas or above crowds, though many people appear ignorant of these rules or happy to flout them.

In October, at the Euro 2016 qualifier in the Serbian capital Belgrade, the match was halted after a drone carrying an Albanian flag was flown over the stadium, sparking a brawl.

That same month, a man from Nottingham was arrested after a drone was flown over Manchester City's stadium.

The CAA has prosecuted two drone operators relating to safety breaches and warns that ignorance is no defence.

But it is not just troublemakers who are a worry.

Mr Pearson believes that anyone buying a drone should hand over proof of identity, as buyers of mobile phones have to.

"I think the potential for drones to be used by terrorists is a very serious threat," he says, adding that one drone packed with explosives and sent into the flight path of an aeroplane is not as worrying as hundreds of tiny drones carrying nerve gas.

One hopes that his scenario remains within the bounds of horror movie fiction. But, clearly, the authorities need to work quickly to catch up with the technology.

The Daily Telegraph

urn:contentItem:3S70-MHW0-0048-T31N-00000-00<published>1998-03-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:48:25Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: INDONESIAN FARMER FIGHTS OFF ORANGUTAN</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, March 13 Reuters - A farmer battling forest fires near his garden in East Kalimantan province in Indonesia survived an attack by a 100 kg orangutan, newspapers said today.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The 42-year-old victim, Supaini, was bitten on his leg and hands by a female orangutan, which attacked him last week while he was putting out a forest fire that had come dangerously close to his field in the Kutai regency, reports said.</p><p>The farmer said the orangutan leaped out of the brush and chased him several metres outside his house before he tripped in a hole and fell. The animal then pounced on him and bit him, reports said.</p><p> He said he would have died if his neighbour, Mul, had not seen the chase and, armed with a wooden club and machete, struck the animal, which fell off and ran away. It later died, one paper said.</p><p> Supaini was later taken to hospital and one report said he lost several fingers that had been bitten in the attack.</p><p> The farmer said the orangutan was probably upset by the fires, which have driven the primates out of their jungle habitat in the province's Kutai National Park, reports said.</p><p> Fires are blazing out of control in East Kalimantan on Indonesia's side of Borneo Island.</p><p>REUTERS wjf/mk</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S70-MHW0-0048-T31N-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="206"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty.
